Key Arguments: The proposed Bill threatens freedom of speech and democratic values.
Appointing the government as an arbitrator of truth is dangerous.
The Bill will lead to self-censorship and actual censorship due to fear of penalties.
Existing laws already address hate speech and incitement to violence.
The Bill's definitions of misinformation and disinformation are vague and inadequate.
The Bill could stifle political criticism and scientific discourse.
Historical examples show that accepted truths can later be proven false.
Notable Quotes: Freedom of expression, opinions and ideas are the keystone and lifeblood of democracy.
Appointing any government or government body as an arbitrator of truth is frightening both in concept and in application.
Truth can always withstand even the most intense scrutiny.
The Bill seeks to eradicate the principle of 'I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.'
The proposed Bill seeks to unfairly restrict the voices and opinions of regular citizens.
